issues.description: The problem statement (Part 2, client controller description) says "Each method takes a Consumer<List<Note>> parameter" while the exercise and template/solution APIs actually require Consumer<List<Person>> for the PersonController methods. This is a documentation/type mismatch in the problem description that could confuse students about the expected method parameter types when implementing the PersonController.
issues.suggested_fix: Correct the problem statement text to refer to Consumer<List<Person>> (not Consumer<List<Note>>) when describing the PersonController methods. This aligns the documentation with the template and solution method signatures and removes potential confusion.

issues.description: The problem statement (Part 2, method parameter description) incorrectly refers to Consumer<List<Note>> for the PersonController methods, while both the template and the solution code define and expect Consumer<List<Person>>. This mismatched identifier in the textual specification (using 'Note' instead of 'Person') creates a conceptual mapping confusion: students reading the problem may expect note-lists as callbacks or try to implement the wrong generic type, even though the code skeleton and final implementation use Person.
issues.suggested_fix: Update the problem statement text to refer to Consumer<List<Person>> (and to say the consumer takes the internal list of persons) so it matches the template and solution code. Concretely, replace the phrase "Each method takes a `Consumer<List<Note>>` parameter... This consumer takes the internal list of persons as a parameter" with: "Each method takes a `Consumer<List<Person>>` parameter, which must be called after a response is received — the consumer will be passed the controller's internal list of Person objects."
